content:
I didn't try to solve this problem (although i have an idea of how to proceed) but i think it's a really cool one !!
I was wondering if you provided a test case that checked if each grid cell is used one time at most (for each word): cf : "Each cell of the grid may be used only once."
For exemple : in the test case 1 : the word EOE should not be "true" because you'd be using the "E" twice

I like it, although I'm not really sure about the time limit. I've tried it, but I got the rules wrong. I've made it for ~8 minutes using any letter from the grid not only the adjacent ones. I guess that its doable, but it really depends on the language. I guess in c#/java/python/js/ruby will be relatively easy to do, if you get the right approach.
Small bending of true Boggle rules for case Test 3 - normally words should be at least 3 letters long ;)
Though I like the idea, I wonder if it's not even too difficult for a 20 minutes clash.

I designed the statement and cases first and tried to solve it afterwards and made it in just about 20 minutes so I think it fits.
I agree it is quite near the limit, though.

Yes, there is 'DEAD' in test case 1.
But I added another one anyway :)

I also needed around 20 minutes, but that was because of a stupid mistake about not resetting the array of "used letters".
I think it's doable in 20 minutes.
